comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I don't think they exist today, which may point to a site later resumed for Sydney Harbour Bridge construction.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: 1923? Another image of the flats from the Marine Services Board collection can be seen here - www.afloat.com.au/afloat-magazine/2010/june-2010/State_Re... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] MSB 4599 (original ID) might have more details in it's description?

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Tramlines and caternary and  resumed for Sydney Harbour Bridge construction should nail it down

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] My first thoughts were Millers Point, the building style is similar to other buildings in the area. Could be between Cumberland Street and Lower Fort Street - and as MHP suggests demolished for bridge construction.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
How about they are somewhere near those other Day Street photos, and that is the Erskine Street - King Street tramway?

See c.1927 map at original size for tram route detail - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6662642331/]

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: The Millers Point tram went down George Street, up past the Harbour View Hotel into Lower Fort Street, around Argyle Place and back, the route still exists.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] Don't you wish you had Google Street View for the period 1788 - 2008?

However, BC you may be onto something - but the street looks too wide for Day Street

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think these "Worker Flats" replaced earlier condemned buildings on the east side of Day Street (or whatever it was called then or since) between Erskine and King Streets. See the lie of the land in this (c.1901?) photo (not yet on Flickr) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... . I think the wall at the far right end is the same in both, but I am not going to count the bricks! The Bristol Arms back entrance ties it in with this - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3810909678/] and to the left (north) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/9468114425/] and to the right (south) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/9417082221/] Almost a p@n0r@m@!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It is really difficult to visualize all this because whole blocks and streets were obliterated in the 1960s and 1970s to make way for the Western Distributor, and subsequent redevelopments of Darling Harbour foreshores. None of us is seeing anything recognizable. One of the few constant landmarks is the Bristol Arms Hotel in Sussex Street, back entrance in the old Day Street. I think this is as near to the photo as possible on GoogleMapsStreetView - goo.gl/maps/ZSdw0

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, I think you have cracked the case! And to pick up your point about change, just think of the changes ahead with Barangaroo casting its supposed new life into the area! What's left of our maritime history is disappearing in front of our eyes.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I rather like that ... next time I see the Minister for Planning I'll drop it into the conversation!

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: My guess is George Street about where the Four Seasons Hotel is now as you can see similar buildings, trams, same topography and an overhead bridge in this 1953 aerial photo at that location ?
